did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Collection includes personal and professional materials regarding his travels and work at Cornell

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Professor of Soil Science. Robert Demorest Miller grew up in Columbia, Mo., earned a B.S. from the University of Missouri in 1940, an M.S. from the University of Nebraska in 1941, and a Ph.D. from Cornell University in 1948. During 1944-1945, he served as an air traffic and air defense controller in the Pacific in the Army Air Corps. On August 28, 1945, he was a member of a small advance party sent to Atsugi Air Base near Tokyo to prepare for the major American landings beginning the occupation of Japan. Shortly after landing, he raised the first American flag over Japan, on the radio mast of a C-47, two days before American combat troops began the actual armed occupation. He wrote about his wartime experiences in the book: "Descent from Niitaka, 1941-1945: First Flag Over Japan." After the war, he worked at the University of California at Berkeley, returning to Cornell in 1952 where he remained until his retirement in 1987. From 1964 to 1965, he served as assistant to the Provost Dale Corson and from 1967 to 1971 as dean of the faculty, in which position he played a role in the peaceful resolution of the Cornell '69 crisis, remaining a lifelong friend of President James Perkins. He is considered by his colleagues to be a "Founding Father" of soil physics. Robert Miller died on April 11, 2011.

did.unittitle: Series I. Cornell University Material and Correspondence

scopecontent.p: Contains disks, photos, journals, and notes
Cornell '69 Liberalism and the Crisis of the American University by Donald A. Downs, with comments by R.D. Miller
Newspaper Clippings about '69 and Letter Correspondence with Cornell Faculties
The Chimes of Freedom Flashing by Caleb S. Rossiter. Removed and catalogued separately.
Transcript of Statement, Correspondence James Perkins (1995), and others
Includes"A Failure to Communicate: James Perkins, COSEP, and Black Power at Cornell" Honors Thesis by Eric Rauchway and An Article by Keith R. Johnson

Miscellany, contains calender (1967-1968),a thesis draft by unknown author, Cornell University Student Faculty Board on Student Conduct Notice of Hearing(1968), a photo, notes, and a letter from Davis (2003)

did.unittitle: Cornell '69 More Post-event Materials: Downs, Rossiter, others
Collection of Newspaper on the 20th Anniversary of the Willard Straight Hall Takeover and Speech Draft

scopecontent.p: Newspaper and Journal Collection

did.unittitle: General Legislation of the University Faculty and Extracts from Its Records

scopecontent.p: Includes a private letter to his brothers and sisters describing his perspective on the situation, correspondence, clippings, Newsweek magazine, speeches, Henderson Commission information

Transcript of an oral history interview conducted by Gould P. Colman as part of the Challenge to Governance Project. With index and correspondence regarding the oral history and its restrictions. See also archives 13-6-1285 for the audio tapes.

Includes information and correspondence regarding the death of Perkins, Perkins prize, Ari Van Tienhoven Tom Jones, DVD-1764 of "Cornell 1969: Key Issues Then and Now. A University Faculty Forum, 3 May 1999, Kennedy Hall;" "The 30th Anniversary of WSH Takeover" panel discussion, Memorial Room, Willard Straight Hall, 19 April 1999, the DVD also includes relevant news clippings. Also a copy of a 1978 letter sent to Perkins from the President of Oberlin College Robert Fuller about increasing enrollment of black students that Perkins forwarded to Miller in 1995.

did.unittitle: Copy of Correspondence of James A. Perkins and Robert D. Miller
Correspondence between James A. Perkins and John R. Silber (President of Boston University), and Newspaper Clippings about Them
Invitations, Photos, and Pamphlets for James A. Perkins Prize for Interracial Understanding and Harmony
Series II. Correspondence (Academic, Scientific, and Personal)
Correspondence with Cornell University and Some Other Institutions
Scientific Correspondence with Dean of Faculty

scopecontent.p: Contains Correspondence with Frank H.T. Rhodes and Alfred E. Kahn
Contains Correspondence with Alfred E. Kahn

did.unittitle: Dean of the Faculty Correspondence (Not Related to Cornell '69) 1

scopecontent.p: Contains a sub-series of National Science Foundation

did.unittitle: Dean of the Faculty Correspondence (Not Related to Cornell '69) 2

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from daughter Anne Miller, Herbert Cahoon of the Pierpont Morgan library and Morris Bishop regarding Anne's interest in witchcraft and desire to become a witch. Also correspondence regarding an amusing anecdote at Alice Cook's retirement involving David Burak and a joke about the Cornell mace.
Correspondence regarding Robert and Beulah's anniversary. Correspondence include Keith Kennedy, Dale Corson, and war buddy Captain Walter Huckbee.

Correspondence and clipping regarding his election to the position of Dean of Faculty from Royse Murphy and Rolph Fairchild. Also a thank you note to a Mrs. Burton (a figure from his childhood) from Miller describing his work. Also a note of congratulations on retirement from Marlin Cline.

Includes letters and photographs from Perkins, Corson, Rhodes. Also a program from the Cornell Centennial Dinner. A photograph of Perkins shaking hands with Tom Jones inscribed "Without Bob Miller's cool head there would be no handshake."
Letters from Miller's father Dean Merritt Miller and one to his wife.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to wife Beulah "Buty" from Russia

scopecontent.p: Letters and ephemera sent to his wife while he was in Russia
Letters from colleagues and grad students. Includes letter to Dale Corson on soil physics. Also a floppy disk (FD-340) of soil correspondence
Correspondence Miller's trip to Moscow State University and Ershov's visit to Cornell. Includes photographs of Ershov and of Russian trip.
Scientific correspondence with Miller's brother Professor Edward E Miller of the University of Wisconsin.

scopecontent.p: Prepared as an addendum to a revised version of Hillel's Soil and Water, Physical Principles and Processes

did.unittitle: Scientific work and lectures from Russia trip

scopecontent.p: Reports on thruway, pipeline and cold region soil heaving projects

Skits and speeches written, namely for retirements of staff in the Agronomy Department. Includes items regarding Mark Barlow, Marlin Cline, Mike Peech, Ed Lemon, Bob Musgrave, Earl Stone, Paul Zwerman, Wright, Brady, Aldrich, others. Also audio tapes (tr-10890 Zwerman, Drosdoff; tr-10891 Lemon; tr-10892 Inceptisol, Peech, Zwerman, Drosdoff) and slides of these speeches.

scopecontent.p: Includes photographs from trips to Europe, including Germany, Munich, Heidelberg, Oberwesel, Burg Schonburg, Dresden, Nordlingen, Frankfurt, Dinklesbuhl, Austria, Innsbruch, France, Verdun, England, Stonehenge, Scotland, Edinburgh, golfing, Ireland, Lyons Kansas salt mine, geoogy field trip, Boulder Colorado, Bill Cargill, Dr. Bronson, Wyoming, William C. Warnerson, possibly University of Missouri, family photos, tap day,

Series IX. Personal and Family Materials

scopecontent.p: The papers of Prof. Miller's father Merritt Finley Miller are in the University of Missouri archives and the Missouri State Historical Society archives
This is Prof. Miller's high school. The folder includes his correspondence with the school, speech to 1961 class, and a German song book.
Humorous (re: neighbor's dog), letter re '82 trip to Moscow, notes and account of '73 trip to Siberia, Retirement of Nile Brady-Sketch

did.unittitle: Article on Robert D. Miller and Edward E. Miller: "The Agronomy Brothers"
Family History, Newspaper copy of a report on Edward Mix, First Cousin of Merritt F. Miller
East-Central Illinois Landforms and Ecosystems in the Making 20,000 Years by Elisabeth M. Hanson

scopecontent.p: Elisabeth Hanson is Prof. Miller's sister.
Records family's 1933-34 sabbatical trip to Germany throughout Europe, kept by Prof. Miller's mother Flora Grace Ernst Miller. Front page picture drawn by youthful Prof. Miller
Records family's 1933-34 sabbatical trip to Germany throughout Europe.
Records family's 1933-34 sabbatical trip to Germany throughout Europe.

did.unittitle: Letter from Sam Walton, the founder of Walmart
A Photograph of Obama, with the Signature of Joe Biden Printed
Statement of Elisabeth Hanson (Prof. Muller's sister) regarding Being on the Andrea Doria
Autobiography of Carl Julius Ernest (Prof. Miller's Maternal Grandfather)

scopecontent.p: Carl Julius Ernst's Papers are in the Nebraska Historical Society

did.unittitle: Copy of Note Scrap and Remark Book of Edward Eddy Miller (Prof. Miller's Grandfather), with Prof. Miller's Introduction

scopecontent.p: E.E.Miler served in Ohio regiment. The original is in Ohio Historical Society collection.

did.unittitle: Prof. Miller's Address and Appointment Books 1-3
A Small Electrical Piece of Lab Equipment with A Brass Part Machined by Prof. Miller

scopecontent.p: Includes photos as a baby, wedding photo, family photos, photos from Cornell, image of Miller being interviewed by Bob Simon during Cornell 69.

Includes 1966 family letter, files regarding employment, passports, letter to the editor about Jack Musick, pamphlet "The Story of an Emigrant Boy", awards, invite to a cocktail party from Adlai Stevenson, University of Missouri 1940 diploma, account book kept by Miller 1935-1936, Grandparent book describing the life or Miller's sister Elisabeth Marie Miller describing her life which is informative about Robert's early life as well, birth certificate, resumes, Ithaca Journal article about potholes, envelope containing keys that may have belonged to his office in Caldwell Hall.

did.unittitle: The University in Transition by James A. Perkins

scopecontent.p: Inscribed to Miller by Perkins.
David h. Hickman High School yearbook, annotated by Miller and classmates.

did.unittitle: Prof. Miller's Address and Appointment Books
Scrapbook from Junior and High School, and College

scopecontent.p: Items from Jefferson Junior High School Columbia Missouri, Hickman High School, programs, report cards, photographs, Boy Scouts of America cards, University of Missouri items, Barnwarmin' programs, Alpha Zeta material, correspondence.

scopecontent.p: Explosion of American B 24 bomber, taken by Prof. Miller beside foxhole

did.unittitle: World War II and Military Materials

scopecontent.p: Includes orders, correspondence about his memorabilia with museums, photographs, sketches, correspondence with the Veterans Administration and regarding his lectures to high schools. Also a letter written to the Committee on the Armed Services from April 3, 1993 on Miller's thoughts on gays in the military.

did.unittitle: CDs of photographs related to WWII

scopecontent.p: Niitaka photos (raising flag, Nagasaki), Interview Circus, Museum Presentation (D-Day)

Miller, D. Robert. Descent from Niitaka 1941-1945 First Flag over Japan. Ithaca, NY: Cayuga Press, 2002
Rossiter, S. Caleb. The Chimes of Freedom Flashing. Washington, DC.: TCA Press, 1996

Alexis Lawrence Romanoff. The University Campus. Ithaca, NY: The Cayuga Press, 1960, Inscribed by the author to the Miller family with laid in Romanoff business card and verse written for the Cornell Centennial.
